title: White Horse Trail Walking Route

images.title: Roger Gittins / Westbury White Horse
images.caption: View of the Westbury White Horse at the start of the walk. Construction lines of the concrete surface now visible; an illusion shattered! The earthwork ditch around the top is part of Bratton Camp, an Iron Age fort and National Monument.

images.title: Maurice Pullin / CC BY-SA (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0)
images.caption: West Lavington from White Horse Trail

images.title: David Howard / The White Horse, Cherhill
images.caption: The White Horse, Cherhill

images.title: Brian Robert Marshall / White Horse Trail, west of Beckhampton
images.caption: West of Beckhampton. The byway, for such it is, also forms the boundary between parliamentary consituencies, Devizes, to the right, and North Wiltshire.

images.title: Brian Robert Marshall / White Horse Trail, near Broad Hinton, Wiltshire
images.caption: Near Broad Hinton. The long distance path doubles as a farm track along this stretch. In the far distance is west Swindon. The windmill at the right is at square SU1065983468, approximately.

images.title: Brian Robert Marshall / A view from the White Horse Trail, Highway Hill
images.caption: A view from the trail at Highway Hill. A crop is germinating in the field north of the trail. The small area of woodland isn't named on the maps.

images.title: Brian Robert Marshall / Windmill Hill from the White Horse Trail, Winterbourne Monkton
images.caption: Windmill Hill from the trail, near Winterbourne Monkton. The trail is a bridleway on this stretch and is one of three main routes to the hill.

images.title: Doug Lee / On the White Horse Trail to Oldbury Castle
images.caption: On the White Horse Trail to Oldbury Castle.  A view here along the trail as it runs up to the old hillfort of Oldbury Castle.

description: This is a circular long distance, waymarked trail running through Wiltshire. It starts at the Westbury White Horse and runs through Pewsey, Marlborough, Broad Town, Cherhill, Devizes, Steeple Ashton and Bratton. The walk runs through some beautiful Wiltshire countryside and also visits fascinating historical sites such as the Avebury Stones and Silbury Hill. Other highlights include the Lansdowne Monument at the Cherhill White Horse near the watershed of the River Avon and the River Thames. Near here you'll also pass Hackpen Hill and it's associated white horse. Also known as the Broad Hinton White Horse it was created in 1838 to commemorate the coronation of Queen Victoria. There's also a long waterside section along the Kennet and Avon Canal through Devizes and wonderful views across the Vale of Pewsey around Pewsey.
